Elliott Coleman, Head of the
Writing Seminars Department,

he stayed at the request of the

functional level in that
department during a period of

offerings long after his
retirement. Courses offered this
year include the popular Words
and Ideas Seminars in Fiction

It a day and age when universities must borrow
from their endowment funds to make ends meet,
dependence on private contributions has increased
tremendously. A current fear among many college
presidents, Dr. Muller included, is that the Federal Aid
to Higher Eduation Act will promulgate
misconceptions among contributors as to the degree of
federal relief involved.
At the present time, not one penny has been
appropriated. President Nixon signed an authorization
bill into law early in the summer which creates the
impression that some $6.5 billion will be headed
toward the nations campuses. Nixon called for $3
billion for higher education in January, but there is no
sign of any Administration budget request for the
appropriations bill which must pass both houses of
Congress as well as the Oval Office before the money
becomes available. The authorization bill spent three
months in committees and two months in
House-Senate Conference before reaching the
President.
There is little foundation to the argument that the
institutions themselves will benefit significantly, even
if (a big if) a $6.3 billion appropriation bill should be
signed into law by the President before the end of this
legislative session. Since student aid programs must be
fully funded before institutional aid can be considered,
such an appropriation would not diminish the burden
private contributors now bear in assuming the costs of
higher education.

HCI overcomes problems
By ALLEN SHORT
House Center, Inc., a private
drug counseling group one time
part of Hopkins Committee on
Drug Education (CODE),appears
to have overcome its difficulties
of last winter involving financial
accountability and now is
offering a neighborhood program
of drug education and
counseling. Presently located at
Huntington and 30th Streets, the
group is headed by Charles
Deems, President of the
Remington Improvement
Association. Steven Harris, a
former Legal Aid lawyer, is
Director of the Center's
Programs.
.According to Robert
Fitzpatrick, Dean of Students,
Second District City Councilman,
and one of House Center's
Original incorporaters, the group
IS now
well-established in the
Remington neighborhood.
Programs
House Center offers
r ecreational facilities such as
PIng-pong, billiards, and
television to the area's youth.
Fitzpatrick describes the program
°fferings as an effort to give

Remington teenagers an
alternative to Baltimore Street
life, and consequently, to drug
usage.
Another dimension of the
Center's offerings has been its
Adult Education Program,
created to inform area parents of
the different types, symptoms,
and dangers of drug abuse. The
group is currently co-sponsoring,
along with Hopkin's CODE, a
seminar series on drug usage. It is
hoped that the seminars will
serve to broaden the adult
community's awareness of drug
problems in Baltimore.
Past Problems Overcome
In January and early February
of last winter, the group suffered
problems ranging from H.E.W.'s
failure to deliver promised
operating funds, to charges levied
at them of mismanagement and
irresponsible, unaccountable use
of previously received funds.
At that time, Fitzpatrick
wrote in a letter to H.E.W.
Secretary Elliot Richardson "..I
am writing to request an
immediate suspension of funds
for House Center, Inc., pending a
reappraisal of the entire

program." In the letter,
Fitzpatrick went on to explain
that the staff of the Center could
account for neither the $3,983
initial allocation of the $40,000
grant appropriated it by H.E.W.,
nor some $7,500 loaned to the
Center by the University.
He added that staff resumes
were not available and did not
even exist. Fitzpatrick also cited
the fact that, according to the
terms of the H.E.W. grant, the
funds for the program were to be
used in the Remington area.
House Center had moved its
location several times, he
explained, with each new
location being outside the
Remington neighborhood.
The responsibility for such
mismanagement, wrote
Fitzpatrick, was largely H.E.W.'s,
since the Department had failed
to monitor the group's financial
expenditures and had made no
effort to determine the group's
efficacy. The University's $7,500
loan to the group was necessary,
he continued, because H.E.W.
had failed to release needed
operating funds according to the
timetable of the grant.

During a game, Brandy can be
seen on the sidelines intently
peering onto the playing field.
Should trouble arise, Brandy is
usually the first one to spot it. If
the situation warrants, Brandy
will sprint out to give aid to the
stricken athlete, although most
of the time the player is not
seriously hurt and resumes
playing or walks to the bench
under his own power.
Occasionally Brandy is forced
to make crucial decisions. Should
a player be kept out of a game?
How extensive are game-incurred
injuries? Should the injured be
sent to the hospital? These
decisions often make the
difference between whether an
athlete plays again, walks again,
or even lives.
Whirlpool Baths
After an injury, rehabilitation
is required. Whirlpool baths,
hydrocolator pads, sound
machines, and a diathermy are
some of the equipment available
for use in the training room.
Operation and supervision of this
equipment and taping take up
most of Brandy's time.
But he still finds time to treat
professors, students, alumni, and
friends of the University. In
addition, high school players
from Baltimore City, Baltimore
County, and Anne Arundel
County find their way to the
Hopkins training room. Even
members of the Baltimore press
corps and the professional sports
teams seek out Brandy for one of
his "special treatments."
During the spring, Brandy has
handled the training duties of the
Carling's, Mt. Washington,
Maryland, Schaefer, and Towson
Lacrosse Clubs. Treatment was
also given to the members of the
touring_ Austrolian All-Star

Old Bays

assistant trainer for the old
Baltimore Bays soccer team and
cared for the St. Louis, Dallas,
and Kansas City teams when they
came into Baltimore. Brandy has
also treated the visiting
professional baseball and football
teams when they have requested
help.

Athletic Trainers Association

was theChairman-at-Large and
chief troubleshooter. At the
Convention, he received a
certificate of advanced standing
from the Baltimore Heart
Association for closed chest

similar to the one he got from

In addition, the NATA

By NILS BRUBAKER
The Johns Hopkins Blue Jays
opened their 1972 football
season last Saturday with a
decisive 19-7 victory over
Muhlenberg College. Hopkins
dominated the game both
offensively and defensively,
tallying twice as many first
downs as Muhlenberg (20 to 10),
and amassing over twice as many
total yards(363 to 168).
Tight end Rick Kowalchuk
scored twice for the victors on
short passes from quarterback
Jack Thomas, while defensive
back Billy Nolan electrified the
crowd with an 82-yard punt
return for a touchdown. The
home team's only scoring play
came on a 2-yard run by halfback
Ken Hedden in the third period.
The contest saw the Jays jump
out to an early lead, which the
Mules hardly threatened
throughout the contest. In the
middle of the first quarter, Jack
Thomas marshalled his troops on
an 88-yard march to the game's
first score. The drive featured
powerful running from halfback
Tim Doyle, who by the game's
end had notched 121 of the
team's 234 yards on the ground.
The scoring came on a 2-yard
pass from Thomas to Kowalchuk
with 6:32 on the clock. Thomas
kicked the extra point.
After the ensuing kick-oft,

Little Billy Nolan took the punt

grasps of the frustrated
Muhlenberg defenders. With the
PAT try unsuccessful, this made
the score 13-0, Hopkins.

the scoreless second period. The
Mules moved the ball inside the

possession on downs as the Jays'
defense stiffened. Immediately
afterwards, Hopkins began
another sustained drive.

By CHUCK SLONIM
Haverford College took
advantage of an ineffective
showing by Johns Hopkins to
humiliate the Blue Jays, 4-1, in
Saturday's soccer opener at
Haverford.
The Blue Jays put their feet to
the ball well throughout the
game, demonstrating good
passing and moving the ball well
on offense. In fact, Hopkins
dominated possession of the ball
for a majority of the ninety
minute game.
However, when Haverford's
hot shot right wing, Dan Kim,
took the first shot on the
Hopkin's goal for his team and
scored, a different taste entered
the mouths of the Jays.
Senior Marc Manzione tied the
score with an unassisted goal
some five minutes later, but
Haverford retaliated within the
next minute of play to take a 2-1
lead which would have sufficed
as a final score.

Hopkins definitely outclassed
the Haverford team. Now that
Haverford no longer has a
football team it seemed as
though they decided to put the
roughness of the football game
into their soccer. It was obvious
that they were a much more
physical team than the Blue Jays
who continuously had their
offensive plays disrupted by
penalties, a great many of which
went unnoticed by the officials.
Defeat
Haverford scored two more
times, once more in the first half
and once in the second to drop
the Blue Jays to a 4-1 defeat in
their first game of their season.
The booters will be trying not
only to even their losing record,
but also to avenge a 2-0 defeat in
the worst possible field
conditions in last year's game
against Towson State. The Blue
Jays will play host to the Tigers
this Saturday at the soccer field
at 12 noon.
